title.text: Passive Diagnosis incorporating the PHQ-4 for Depression and Anxiety

abstractContent.text: Depression and anxiety are the two most prevalent mental health disorders worldwide, impacting the lives of millions of people each year.
In this work, we develop and evaluate a multilabel, multidimensional deep neural network designed to predict PHQ-4 scores based on individuals written text.
Our system outper-forms random baseline metrics and provides a novel approach to how we can predict psy-chometric scores from written text.
Additionally , we explore how this architecture can be applied to analyse social media data.

introductionContent.text: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), major depressive disorder 1 is the largest cause of disability worldwide, with a lifetime prevalence rate between 15% and 17% ().
Depression is highly co-morbid with several other mental disorders, the most prevalent of which is a generalized anxiety disorder.
Almost 50% of individuals diagnosed with depression will also be diagnosed with anxiety (.
As a result, many clinicians will investigate for the presence of both disorders at the time of diagnosis.
To do so, psychometric questionnaires are often employed as a quick and reliable initial assessment tool, the most common of which is the Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ).
The PHQ-4 is a short form questionnaire design to access the presence or absence of the core symptoms in depression and anxiety).
The questionnaire has demonstrated both high validity and reliability across several languages and cultures (.
Hereafter referred to as simply depression.
Hereafter referred to as simply anxiety.
Despite the usefulness of these questionnaires, there is still a reliance on individuals actively seeking a diagnosis from a medical professional before they can be applied.
Research has shown that those suffering depression and anxiety often are unaware their symptoms are due to a medical disorder and attribute them to poor mood or external factors ().
This presents a unique challenge in the medical community, in how to inform and encourage individuals to come forward for diagnosis.
have proposed the concept of passive diagnosis, also known as highperformance medicine.

This term refers to the ability for machine learning algorithms to constantly monitor an individuals health and inform the individual if certain changes are evidence of a possible disorder in the future.
This is in comparison to the traditional concept of active diagnosis where an individual suffering certain symptoms would actively seek out a medical diagnosis.
Examples of applications in this domain include DeepCare, which is an end-to-end application designed to diagnose a wide range of disorders (.
Such systems allow clinicians to either prevent a disorder occurring or provide early intervention to minimise its effects.
